37:42 Caption: The resulting corner from Gaston Silva (Granada CF) is cleared.

47:53 Caption: Nothing more will happen in this game as the referee blows for full time.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a scintillating performance that demonstrated their dominance and prowess, Real Madrid triumphed with a resounding 4-0 victory over Granada CF at the Estadio Nuevo Los Cármenes. From the outset, the match exuded anticipation and excitement, and Real Madrid wasted no time in setting the tone for the encounter.

The game commenced with Real Madrid kicking off, and within the first few moments, the intensity was palpable. The first breakthrough came remarkably early—precisely at 02:17—when Real Madrid seized the opportunity to take the lead. The attack was coordinated with precision and resulted in a goal that sent shockwaves through the Granada CF defense. Unable to maintain possession, Granada CF was quickly on the back foot, and their subsequent attempts to regain control were in vain.

Just a minute later at 03:13, Granada CF restarted the game in hopes of finding an equalizer. However, the pressure from Real Madrid was relentless, forcing Granada CF into defensive mode. The ball frequently changed possession during the initial phases, with clearance after clearance becoming the order of the day for the home team.

By 04:26, Real Madrid showed their discipline by meticulously executing a throw-in, continuing their determined pursuit of another goal. Yet, an offside call at 05:14 momentarily halted their momentum. Real Madrid, undeterred, responded with rapid clearance efforts and throw-ins that kept the pressure mounting on Granada CF.

At the 10:05 minute mark, Real Madrid doubled their lead with another stunning goal. This time it was James Rodriguez who showcased his skill with a perfectly timed header after receiving a splendid cross. The ball sailed into the middle, producing a moment of sheer brilliance that mesmerized the spectators. Granada CF was once again tasked with restarting the game, but their efforts to construct any meaningful attack were thwarted by Real Madrid's resolute defense.

The game continued with a series of throw-ins and clearances, reflecting the high-paced nature of the contest. Granada CF's attempts to breach Real Madrid's defensive line were met with robust challenges, often resulting in fouls which disrupted the flow of the game. Notably, Lucas Vazquez's aggressive play earned a free-kick for Granada CF at 21:47, but this opportunity was squandered as the long-range effort was intercepted by Real Madrid's defenders ten seconds later.

One of the critical moments for Granada CF occurred at 22:00 when they were awarded an indirect free-kick. Despite the opportunity, their set-piece execution was less than effective, as one of the defenders adeptly intercepted the ball to negate the threat. This missed chance seemed to encapsulate Granada CF's struggles throughout the match.

Contrastingly, Real Madrid's offense continued to operate like a well-oiled machine. At 29:27, Alvaro Morata latched onto an excellent pass just outside the box and unleashed a thunderous strike that rattled the crossbar before nestling into the net, registering their third goal of the match. Granada CF's defense was left in tatters, and their attempts to respond proved ineffective as they kicked off once again desperately seeking a glimmer of hope.

As the first half progressed, further discipline and tactical awareness from Real Madrid saw them maintaining possession and continually probing Granada CF's defensive weaknesses. A throw-in here, a clearance there; Real Madrid maintained their offensive pressure. At 34:25, Morata struck again, receiving the ball inside the box and calmly dispatching it under the crossbar to score the fourth goal. The clinical nature of Real Madrid's attacks exemplified their superiority on the pitch.

Granada CF's Adrian Ramos had a notable opportunity at 37:08, but his long-range shot sailed wide, epitomizing the home team's faltering efforts. Despite a spirited reception of a pass, his poor shot showcased the gulf in quality between the two sides. Moments like this became frequent as Granada CF struggled to find their rhythm and provide any substantial threat to Real Madrid's goal.

The Real Madrid offensive display continued to dazzle as they created chances with relative ease. At 41:43, Lucas' solo effort from the edge of the box hit the post, epitomizing their attacking flair and near-dominance. Casemiro's efforts were similarly impressive, although his strike just before the referee blew for half-time failed to hit the target.

With the commencement of the second half, Granada CF made substitution adjustments in hopes of altering the course of the game. However, these changes offered little reprieve. The early stages were marred by disruptions, with multiple throw-ins and ball clearances dominating the play. David Lomban replaced Rene Krhin for Granada CF, signaling Tony Adams' strategic adjustments to reinforce his side.

The defensive solidity of Real Madrid remained uncompromising. Granada CF's attempts to break through were met with robust counter-actions, clearances, and organized defensive structures. By 06:09, Marco Asensio found himself being flagged offside—an indication of Real Madrid’s willingness to push forward and capitalize on their advantage.

Real Madrid’s tactical substitutions brought fresh energy onto the pitch. At 14:00, Marco Asensio made way for Karim Benzema. Benzema's arrival was marked by his assertive presence in the forward line, pressing the Granada CF defense and creating further opportunities for his teammates. The synergy between Real Madrid players was evident as they continued to close down spaces and control the tempo of the game.

Even amidst Real Madrid's dominance, Granada CF had sporadic moments where they attempted to claw back. Isaac Cuenca’s chip pass into the box at 16:12 was a rare show of ingenuity, although Francisco Casilla quickly intercepted it, denying any goal-scoring opportunity. Moreover, Martin Hongla's blocked shot further highlighted Granada CF's difficulty in finding any substantial openings.

As the second half progressed, Real Madrid continued to showcase their tactical superiority. A formidable defensive line combined with swift attacking transitions saw them dominate possession and consistently press into Granada CF’s half. Key playmaker James Rodriguez continued orchestrating the midfield, delivering dangerous balls into the penalty area, one of which nearly resulted in a goal as Lucas’ powerful shot was expertly saved by Guillermo Ochoa.

Granada CF's resilience was periodically tested. Their sporadic forays into Real Madrid's territory, like Martin Hongla's near-miss header from a corner, were often curtailed by Real Madrid's well-drilled defense. As the game wore on, the disparity in quality became increasingly evident, with Real Madrid's efficiency and tactical acumen outshining Granada CF’s earnest but faltering efforts.

Substitutions continued to shape the momentum. At 22:57, Isco replaced Casemiro, bringing fresh creativity into Real Madrid's attack. This change only solidified Real Madrid's control of the game, as Isco's deft touches and vision provided added flair and stability in midfield.

Granada CF’s struggle to find the back of the net was illustrated by numerous off-target shots. Victorien Angban’s long-range attempts and Adrian Ramos’ wide shots underscored their inability to breach Real Madrid's tight defense. Their frustration was palpable, and Real Madrid's authoritative gameplay compounded their woes.

A meticulous review of the game reveals a consistent pattern of Real Madrid controlling the flow, with seamless transitions between solid defensive actions and precise attacking plays. The final stages of the match witnessed Karim Benzema’s ferocious strike being blocked by Guillermo Ochoa, demonstrating that Granada CF's goalkeeper was one of the few bright spots in an otherwise disappointing display.

As the referee blew the final whistle, the aggregate dominance of Real Madrid was solidified with a 4-0 victory. Remarkable goals from Alvaro Morata and James Rodriguez highlighted their attacking prowess. Their impenetrable defense rendered Granada CF's efforts ineffective throughout the ninety minutes. It was a masterclass in football, showcasing the gulf in quality and highlighting Real Madrid’s position as a formidable force in the league. Their tactical brilliance, individual skill, and collective harmony on the pitch reaffirmed why they are perennial contenders for any title they pursue.
